channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Biden Bans Russian Oil Imports, and Major U.S. Brands Close Outlets
item.description: McDonald’s and Coca-Cola are among those suspending operations. The U.S. rejected a Polish plan to provide fighter jets in Ukraine. Vice President Kamala Harris heads to Poland and Russia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian civilians being evacuated from Irpin as fighting continues between Russian and Ukrainian forces on Tuesday.

item.title: Live Updates: South Korean Presidential Candidates Diverge on North Korea
item.description: The two front-runners hold drastically different positions on how to deal with Kim Jong-un’s nuclear threat. One favors resuming dialogue, while the other has been more confrontational.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times

item.title: Meet South Korea’s Swing Voters: Young, Broke and Angry
item.description: Frustrated over housing prices, a lack of job opportunities and a widening income gap, the once-reliable voting bloc is undecided and will most likely elect the next president.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: The banners of presidential candidates in downtown Seoul in February. On Wednesday, South Koreans will elect a new president, and all eyes are on young people. ​

item.title: How Russia’s War in Ukraine Complicates the Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: With the world eager to wean itself from Russian oil after the invasion of Ukraine, negotiators appeared close to signing a revived nuclear pact with Iran and lifting sanctions. Then Moscow put up a hurdle.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran in 2010. A new nuclear deal would sharply restrict Iran’s nuclear program and allow it to sell its oil freely on the world market.

item.title: Venezuela Releases Imprisoned Americans After Talks With U.S.
item.description: The release of Gustavo Cárdenas, an executive at the U.S. branch of Venezuela’s state oil company, and Jorge Alberto Fernández came after Biden officials moved to thaw relations with Venezuela, long a steadfast Russian ally.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Natalie Kitroeff and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Matias Delacroix/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela in January.

item.title: As Fighting Gets Closer, a Kyiv Hospital Treats the War’s Atrocities
item.description: As Russian bombings have grown more indiscriminate, hospitals in Ukraine have become perilous places to work.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses at Clinical Hospital No. 7 in Kyiv attend to a wounded soldier.

item.title: Two Days of Russian News Coverage: An Alternate Reality of War
item.description: To watch news broadcasts of the fighting in Ukraine on the main state channels in Russia is to witness the extent of the Kremlin’s efforts to sanitize its war.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Mikhael Klimentyev/Sputnik
item.media:description: This photograph made available by Russian state media shows President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with female crew members from Aeroflot on Saturday.

item.title: Moldova Fears It May Be Russia’s Next Target
item.description: Moldova has taken in more Ukrainians, per capita, than any other country. But the closer Russian troops get to Moldova, the more locals consider their own escape plans.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: ​South Korea’s Presidential Election: What to Watch
item.description: ​After a campaign marred by scandals and mudslinging, the country is set to elect its next president amid widespread voter discontent.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line for early voting in Seoul on Friday against a backdrop of election posters for the presidential candidates.

item.title: Ukrainians Trying to Flee to U.K. Face a Confounding Path
item.description: The government has offered a way for U.K. residents to bring over Ukrainian relatives fleeing the war. But families and rights groups say it’s a bureaucratic nightmare that makes it too difficult to get in.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees in Palanca, Moldova, after crossing over from Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief to Visit China
item.description: Michelle Bachelet would be the first official in her position to visit China, which has come under fire for its rights record, in nearly two decades.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling a square last year in front of a mosque in Kashgar, in Xinjiang, where China has been accused of human rights abuses.

item.title: Baltics, in Russia's Shadow, Demand Tougher Stance From West
item.description: “We have no illusions about Putin’s Russia anymore,” said one Baltic official in a meeting with the U.S. secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Associated Press

item.title: How Maori Stepped In to Save a Towering Tree Crucial to Their Identity
item.description: Tāne Mahuta, an ancient tree named after the god of forests in Māori mythology, is threatened by the slow creep of an incurable disease.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Ruth Mcdowall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists visiting Tāne Mahuta, the largest known kauri tree living and part of the Māori mythology, in Waipoua Forest, New Zealand.

item.title: These Syrian Refugees Can't Stay in Denmark, but They Can't Go Home
item.description: Dozens of Syrian asylum seekers are stuck in limbo after the Danish authorities decided it was safe for them to go back home and stripped their residency permits.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Charlotte de la Fuente for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haitham Kurdi from Syria in the communal kitchen of the Kaershovedgaard deportation center in the town of Ikast, Denmark.

item.title: Mexican Women Protest Femicides as President Warns Against Violence
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has been accused of not doing enough to stem the rise in violence against women.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Victoria Razo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the National Palace in Mexico City during the International Women’s Day march on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Western moves to isolate Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Who Is Yoon Suk-yeol?
item.description: Mr. Yoon, the leading conservative candidate, hopes to win the election by appealing to South Koreans who are deeply dissatisfied with the outgoing administration.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Biden Bans Oil Imports From Russia, Warning Gas Prices Will Rise
item.description: Officials said President Biden had struggled for days over the move amid deep concerns about accelerating the already rapid rise in the price of gasoline.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If we do not respond to Putin’s assault on global peace and stability today, the cost of freedom and to the American people will be even greater tomorrow,” President Biden said on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Vows No Surrender in Video to Britain’s Parliament
item.description: In a dramatic video address to Britain’s House of Commons, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said he would never capitulate to the invading Russians.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of the last remaining Ukrainian civilians being evacuated from the town of Irpin across the bridge into Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Tells Congress Putin Is ‘Unlikely to Be Deterred’
item.description: Top U.S. intelligence officials told Congress that the Russian leader had underestimated Ukrainian resolve and Western cohesion but was “doubling down” to achieve his goals.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Avril D. Haines, the director of national intelligence, said Moscow underestimated the strength of Ukraine’s resistance.

item.title: Starbucks, McDonald’s and Others Pause Operations in Russia
item.description: After years of cultivating the Russian market, McDonald’s, Starbucks, PepsiCo and Coca-Cola said they would temporarily close locations or stop selling products there.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Alexander Shcherbak/TASS via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Pushkin Square McDonald’s in 2020. The company said it was temporarily closing its nearly 850 locations in Russia.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s WNBA Impact Is Clear As Fans Await Word from Russia
item.description: Griner, one of the world’s best basketball players, was believed to have been detained in Russia on what customs officials described as drug charges. Fans are worried.
item.dc:creator: Alanis Thames and Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Michael Hickey/Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner of the W.N.B.A.’s Phoenix Mercury is believed to be detained in Russia, but those close to her are not saying much.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Biden Bans Russian Oil
item.description: Plus South Korea is set to elect a new president and Afghan smugglers flourish.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden speaks inside the Roosevelt Room at The White House in Washington, March 6, 2022. President Biden announced the ban on imports of Russian oil shortly before traveling to Texas.

item.title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Leads Olivier Award Nominees
item.description: A revival of the 1966 musical, with Jessie Buckley as Sally Bowles, is up for 11 awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall

item.title: ‘Kony 2012,’ 10 Years Later
item.description: Once the most viral video of all time, the film reads as both a digital relic and a precursor to an era in which footage of conflict dominates the internet.
item.dc:creator: Emma Madden
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Kony 2012,” a film released 10 years ago by the nonprofit Invisible Children, galvanized a global movement and a civilian manhunt for Joseph Kony, the leader of the Lord’s Resistance Army.

item.title: Biden Bans All Imports of Russian Oil Into U.S.
item.description: The British also said they would phase out imports of Russian oil by the end of the year to increase the economic isolation of Russia’s president, Vladimir. V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden announced a ban on oil and gas imports from Russia, the latest step in the intensifying sanctions against the country.

item.title: W.H.O. Condemns Attacks on Health Care Services in Ukraine, Calls for Safe Passage for Medical Supplies
item.description: The organization has confirmed at least 16 attacks on the medical system, which is facing urgent supply shortages.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Giuseppe Lami/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Members of the Italian Red Cross loading a truck with medicine to be distributed to Ukrainians, in Rome last week.

item.title: What Ukrainian Military Reports Are Saying Nearly 2 Weeks Into War
item.description: The Ukrainian military claims to have killed thousands of Russian soldiers and destroyed hundreds of tanks and aircraft. Verifying the figures is challenging.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces disabled a Russian tank in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: China’s Russia Problem
item.description: Things were going very well for China, until the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces with a captured Russian tank.

item.title: The Smugglers’ Paradise of Afghanistan
item.description: For decades, the smuggling trade — of people, drugs and money — has dominated Nimruz Province. Now, as hundreds of thousands of Afghans try to flee, business has further boomed for those who hold the keys to the gate.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Just before midnight, the smugglers picked up two young brothers, ages 4 and 6, and paid the smugglers to take them across the border where their relatives live.

item.title: Poles Welcome Ukrainian Refugees, Unlike in Last Border Crisis
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Polish families have opened their homes to refugees from Ukraine, a sharp contrast to the country’s response to a different crisis last fall at the border with Belarus.

item.title: A 459-Foot Mystery in a Tuscan Port: Is It a Russian’s Superyacht?
item.description: As European authorities go after the luxury assets of oligarchs close to Vladimir Putin, a superyacht cloaked in secrecy has come under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe, Gaia Pianigiani and David D. Kirkpatrick

item.title: Venezuela Could Be Fill-in for Russian Oil, But Critics Fear Aiding Maduro
item.description: U.S. officials are reportedly considering easing sanctions on Venezuelan crude as oil prices have skyrocketed.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Los Taques, Venezuela, in 2017.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An intensifying humanitarian crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Olga Korolyova, left, with a friend in the wrecked kitchen of her home in Mykolaiv, Ukraine on Monday.

item.title: Moderna opens the door to enforcing its vaccine patents in some countries.
item.description: The company had previously pledged not to enforce its Covid vaccine patents anywhere during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A medical staff member prepares a dose of the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine at a clinic on Staten Island last year.

item.title: Allowed to go maskless, some New York City students choose not to.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman, Julianne McShane, Nate Schweber and Lola Fadulu
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stuyvesant High School students walking to class in Lower Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Video: Zelensky Is Seen in His Office for First Time Since Invasion
item.description: The Ukrainian president told his people that he was not afraid or in hiding.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Vlodymyr Zelensky, in Kyiv, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: As Russia’s Military Stumbles, Its Adversaries Take Note
item.description: President Vladimir Putin could still reduce cities in Ukraine to rubble, officials say. But European countries say they are not as intimidated by Russian ground forces as they were in the past.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian forces attacked residential neighborhoods of Mykolaiv, Ukraine, with artillery on Monday.

item.title: Humanitarian Crisis Worsens for Ukrainians Trapped in Russia’s Onslaught
item.description: Two weeks after the invasion began, tens of thousands of Ukrainians are without food, water or power. The Russians are increasingly resorting to indiscriminate shelling to help their forces advance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Andrew E. Kramer and Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian forces unleashed an artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv on Monday, hitting residential neighborhoods with rockets and sending streams of people fleeing.

item.title: Biden Officials Weigh Russian Oil Ban as Gas Prices Soar
item.description: Global stocks dipped on Monday as U.S. officials discussed an oil cutoff, and gas prices hit a national average above $4, up more than 10 percent in a week.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Edward Wong and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas station in Miami Beach, Fla., last week. The cost of gasoline in the United States is approaching record levels.

item.title: Risks to the Brain
item.description: Covid-19 may cause tissue damage and loss of gray matter
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Whet Moser
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Daily reported coronavirus cases in the United States, seven-day average.

item.title: Once Victims in Southeast Europe, Jews Come to Aid Fleeing Ukrainians
item.description: Today, as in the early 1900s, Jews are once again escaping violence in southeast Europe. But the context is radically different — cathartically so for the many Israelis who have come here to join the relief effort.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: Letter ‘Z,’ Symbol of Support for War, Spreads Across Russia
item.description: The letter, painted on Russian military vehicles, is suddenly ubiquitous in Russia, prompting talk of a Kremlin public relations campaign.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The large Z on a billboard in St. Petersburg, Russia, is a symbol of the Russian military.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia escalates attacks on civilians
item.description: Plus new research warning of a drier Amazon and Xi’s relationship with Putin.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian forces unleashed a vicious artillery attack on the southern Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv on Monday.

item.title: Against C.D.C. Advice, Florida to Advise Against Covid Vaccines for Healthy Children
item.description: The C.D.C. has urged parents to get their eligible children vaccinated. “Covid-19 can make children very sick and cause children to be hospitalized,” the agency’s website says.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Alicia Devine/USA Today Network, via Reuters
item.media:description: Dr. Joseph A. Ladapo during a confirmation hearing last month.

item.title: 9/11 Suspect Is Returned to Saudi Arabia for Mental Health Care
item.description: Mohammed al-Qahtani had spent 20 years at Guantánamo Bay, where he was tortured so badly that he was ineligible to be tried at the war crimes court.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The closed Camp X-Ray detention facility on Guantánamo Bay, where Mohammed al-Qahtani was subjected to brutal interrogation.

item.title: Truckers Protest Mandates on D.S. Beltway for a Second Day
item.description: Organizers of a convoy of vehicles protesting mask and vaccine mandates said they would drive another lap around the Beltway on Monday but did not intend to enter the capital.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo and Adam Bednar
item.media:credit: Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators prepare to depart the Hagerstown Speedway in Hagerstown, Md., on Monday.

item.title: With New Limits on Media, Putin Closes a Door on Russia’s ‘Openness’
item.description: The Russian leader is undoing the social freedoms introduced at the end of the Soviet Union, risking a return to total control and ideological isolation.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: An enormous screen on a hotel on the outskirts of Moscow last April displayed Vladimir V. Putin as he gave a speech to the nation.

item.title: Russia, Blocked From the Global Internet, Plunges Into Digital Isolation
item.description: Russian authorities and multinational companies have erected a digital barricade between the country and the West, erasing the last remnants of independent information online.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kremlin in Moscow last month. Russians have been cut off from many Western internet services in a matter of days.

item.title: World’s Known Covid Death Toll Surpasses 6 Million
item.description: And stark vaccination disparities between countries remain, leaving the entire world vulnerable to the threat of a new, deadly variant.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Funeral home employees moving a body outside a makeshift Covid treatment area at a Hong Kong hospital last week.

item.title: A Quebec Restaurant Renames Poutine Dish as a Rebuke of Russia
item.description: Protest against the war in Ukraine has a new cultural front — food and drink names — as people across the world show solidarity with Ukraine by renaming or boycotting Russian-made products.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: John Zada/Alamy
item.media:description: Poutine at Le Roy Jucep, in Quebec.

item.title: Ukrainians Repel Another Russian Assault on Mykolaiv, Officials Say
item.description: As the opposing armies fought outside the strategic port city near the Black Sea, residential areas within Mykolaiv came under intensifying Russian rocket and artillery fire.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times

item.title: Amazon Rainforest May Be Approaching a Critical Tipping Point, Study Finds
item.description: The region is nearing a threshold beyond which its forests may be replaced by grasslands, with huge repercussions for biodiversity and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighting a fire in the Brazilian Amazon near Rio Pardo in 2019.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Welcomes Justin Trudeau in Meeting After Having Had Covid
item.description: The queen received Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada at Windsor Castle on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Photo by Steve Parsons
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II receives Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during an audience at Windsor Castle, on Monday.

item.title: Covid May Cause Changes in the Brain, New Study Finds
item.description: Brain scans before and after infection showed more loss of gray matter and tissue damage, mostly in areas related to smell, in people who had Covid than in those who did not.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: G. Douaud, Anderson Winkler and Saad Jbabdi, University of Oxford and NIH
item.media:description: A digital model of a human brain showing the parts of the brain that lost the most gray matter in the 401 Covid-infected participants in the study, in red-yellow.

item.title: Take a closer look at why American mask makers are going out of business.
item.dc:creator: Joe Nocera
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: DemeTech, a medical supply manufacturer in Miami, has laid off virtually all the employees it hired during the pandemic to make masks.

item.title: Ukraine Takes its Case Against Russia to the UN's Highest Court
item.description: The head of the Ukrainian delegation told the court that “millions are in danger” and accused Moscow of defiling the Genocide Convention.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Phil Nijhuis
item.media:description: Anton Korynevych, Ukraine’s permanent representative to Crimea, and Oksana Zolotaryova, the head of international law at Ukraine’s Foreign Affairs Ministry, spoke to reporters at the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Monday.
